explanations.summary: Proximal tubule has HIGHEST paracellular permeability - 'leaky' tight junctions allow passive water/solute movement. Collecting duct and thick ascending limb have TIGHT junctions. Thin descending limb is permeable to water (transcellular) but not highest paracellular.

whyCorrect.a: The proximal convoluted tubule has the highest paracellular permeability due to its 'leaky' tight junctions. This allows massive passive reabsorption of water following solute reabsorption - ~65% of filtered water is reabsorbed here via paracellular route.

whyIncorrect.b: Collecting duct (with ADH) has increased TRANSCELLULAR water permeability via aquaporin-2 channels, but its tight junctions remain relatively TIGHT, not leaky paracellularly.
whyIncorrect.c: Thick ascending limb of Henle has VERY TIGHT junctions - it's water impermeable. This creates the diluting segment that separates solute from water.
whyIncorrect.d: Thin descending limb is permeable to water (transcellular via aquaporins) but has lower paracellular permeability than proximal tubule.

explanations.summary: MEDULLA contains: loops of Henle (thin segments, descending limbs), collecting ducts (inner portions), vasa recta. CORTEX contains: all glomeruli (cortical AND juxtamedullary), Bowman's capsules, proximal/distal convoluted tubules, juxtaglomerular apparatus.

whyCorrect.b: Thin segment of loop of Henle dips deep into the medulla, especially in juxtamedullary nephrons which create the concentrated inner medulla.
whyCorrect.f: Descending limb of loop of Henle extends into the medulla - longer in juxtamedullary nephrons, shorter in cortical nephrons.
whyCorrect.g: Collecting ducts traverse the medulla vertically, passing through progressively more concentrated interstitium toward the papilla.

whyIncorrect.a: Cortical glomeruli are located in the CORTEX (outer region), not medulla. All glomeruli are in the cortex.
whyIncorrect.c: Bowman's capsule surrounds the glomerulus and is located entirely in the CORTEX.
whyIncorrect.d: Proximal tubule pars CONVOLUTA (convoluted portion) is in the cortex. Only pars recta may extend toward medulla.
whyIncorrect.e: Distal tubule pars convoluta is entirely in the CORTEX, near its own glomerulus.
whyIncorrect.h: Juxtamedullary glomeruli, despite their name, are in the CORTEX (at the corticomedullary junction), not medulla.
whyIncorrect.i: Juxtaglomerular apparatus is at the vascular pole of glomerulus in the CORTEX.

explanations.summary: Tubular epithelium: BRUSH BORDER (microvilli) increases LUMINAL surface for reabsorption. BASAL channels (infoldings) increase basolateral surface for Na-K-ATPase. Na+ entry is PASSIVE (not active) from lumen. Intracellular NEGATIVE potential (-70mV) drives Na+ entry.

whyCorrect.b: The brush border (microvilli) on the LUMINAL (apical) surface multiplies surface area ~20-fold for efficient reabsorption in proximal tubule.
whyCorrect.d: Tubular cells have negative intracellular voltage (~-70mV). This electrical gradient PLUS low intracellular Na+ drives passive Na+ entry from the lumen through channels and cotransporters.

whyIncorrect.a: BASAL channels (basolateral membrane infoldings) multiply the BASAL surface, not luminal surface. They house Na-K-ATPase pumps.
whyIncorrect.c: Na+ is NOT actively transported INTO cells from lumen. Entry is PASSIVE (down electrochemical gradient). Active transport occurs at BASOLATERAL membrane (Na-K-ATPase pumps Na+ OUT of cell).

explanations.summary: CORTEX contains: ALL glomeruli (including juxtamedullary), Bowman's capsules, convoluted tubules, BEGINNING of collecting tubules, juxtaglomerular apparatus. MEDULLA contains: loops of Henle, vasa recta, main collecting duct system.

whyCorrect.a: Juxtamedullary nephron GLOMERULI are in the CORTEX at the corticomedullary junction. Only their LOOPS extend deep into medulla.
whyCorrect.d: Collecting tubules BEGIN in the cortex (cortical collecting ducts) before descending through medulla toward papilla.

whyIncorrect.b: Loop of Henle extends into MEDULLA. While it starts and ends in cortex, the loop itself dips into medulla.
whyIncorrect.c: Vasa recta are specialized capillaries that follow loops of Henle into MEDULLA. They maintain medullary osmotic gradient.
whyIncorrect.e: This is too vague. Cortical nephrons are ENTIRELY in cortex but this doesn't specify which part - loops still dip into outer medulla.

explanations.summary: Medullary structures: thin segment of Henle, descending limb, collecting duct (main portions), vasa recta. Cortical structures: ALL glomeruli, Bowman's capsule, convoluted tubules, juxtaglomerular apparatus.

whyCorrect.a: Thin segment of loop of Henle is located in the medulla - it's the deepest part of the nephron loop.
whyCorrect.e: Collecting duct traverses the entire medulla, becoming increasingly concentrated with urea and electrolytes.
whyCorrect.h: Descending limb of Henle extends into medulla - permeable to water, allowing water extraction into hypertonic interstitium.

whyIncorrect.b: Bowman's capsule encapsulates glomerulus and is entirely in CORTEX.
whyIncorrect.c: ALL glomeruli are in CORTEX. Even juxtamedullary glomeruli are cortical - only their loops extend into medulla.
whyIncorrect.d: Proximal tubule pars convoluta is the CONVOLUTED portion in CORTEX around the glomerulus.
whyIncorrect.f: Juxtamedullary glomeruli are in CORTEX at corticomedullary border. 'Juxta' means 'next to' - they're next to medulla, not in it.
whyIncorrect.g: Juxtaglomerular apparatus (macula densa + JG cells) is at vascular pole of glomerulus in CORTEX.
whyIncorrect.i: Distal tubule pars convoluta is entirely in CORTEX, contacting its own glomerulus at macula densa.
